Title: An interesting inequality $\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{n+k}<\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}, \ n\ge1$
Content:
Here is one of the beautiful inequalities from Elementary inequalities by Mitrovic $$\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{n+k}<\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2},$$
which is easy to prove by calculus using that $\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{n+k}=\log(2)$. Now, the question is How would you prove it without calculus ?
AcceptedAnswer: Cauchy-Schwarz plus creative telescoping and a bit of luck: $$\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n+k}<\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n+k-1}\sqrt{n+k}}\stackrel{CS}{\leq}\sqrt{n\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{n+k-1}-\frac{1}{n+k}\right)}=\color{red}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}.$$
